body: I assume the stuck loop is related to #3247

> I assume the stuck loop is related to #3247

Yep it is

> @Wolfmyths if you attach a debugger and pause it during the unresponsiveness, you can confirm my findings by telling us if the debugger halts within SFML's code for processing GL errors (`glCheckError` function in SFML).

Yup, prints the same error on SFML 3.0

```
An internal OpenGL call failed in "RenderWindow.cpp"(113).
Expression:
   glGetIntegerv(GLEXT_GL_FRAMEBUFFER_BINDING, reinterpret_cast<GLint*>(&m_defaultFrameBuffer))
Error description:
   GL_INVALID_OPERATION
   The specified operation is not allowed in the current state.
```

> I presume a default Qt app redirects the stdout or is just a Win32 app so you can't see the stdout easily, that means you would never see the stream of GL errors being shouted by SFML.

Yes, you have to set an environmental variable for it to capture stdout: `QT_WIN_DEBUG_CONSOLE=1`
I use VSCode so I had to write it into launch.json
@Wolfmyths Thanks, that at least confirms the cause of the problem. Not sure what the best course is here without understanding why.

Did some digging and I have the answers we need for now. This is because we're trying to poll errors without a valid GL context. According to [this resource](https://www.khronos.org/opengl/wiki/OpenGL_Error): 

> Note: No OpenGL function call is valid when an [OpenGL Context](https://www.khronos.org/opengl/wiki/OpenGL_Context) is not made current. Depending on the platform, a call to [glGetError](https://www.khronos.org/opengl/wiki/GLAPI/glGetError) without having a context made current may crash or return any value, including indefinitely returning a valid OpenGL error code. So if you see an infinite loop in such a function, this is likely the reason why 

Having taken a look through the code it seems the flow is : 

1. https://github.com/SFML/SFML/blob/3.0.0/src/SFML/Window/Window.cpp#L126 override of create on the `sf::Window`
2. We then call https://github.com/SFML/SFML/blob/3.0.0/src/SFML/Window/WindowBase.cpp#L114 
3. Then we call the initialize on `sf::WindowBase`, which calls `onCreate()` 
4. `onCreate` is an inherited method which `sf::RenderWindow` has a implemented which tries to do some GL stuff which checks for an error https://github.com/SFML/SFML/blob/7f1162dfea4969bc17417563ac55d93b72e84c1e/src/SFML/Graphics/RenderWindow.cpp#L109

All of that happens before the call to create the context here https://github.com/SFML/SFML/blob/3.0.0/src/SFML/Window/Window.cpp#L129 

Edit:
I tried making the context before we do the init as a potential line swap fix, it results in a crash since we need to have a valid owner window impl instance before we can create the context. Not sure how this all hangs together internally but maybe @vittorioromeo or @binary1248 have a better idea here.

Just as an extra note, seems like the return value of `winId()` is kind of "unreliable" and [might change, if it's a `QWidget`](https://doc.qt.io/qt-6/qwidget.html#winId):

> This value may change at run-time. An event with type [QEvent::WinIdChange](https://doc.qt.io/qt-6/qevent.html#Type-enum) will be sent to the widget following a change in window system identifier.

This doesn't seem to apply to `QWindow`, though.

> Just as an extra note, seems like the return value of `winId()` is kind of "unreliable" and [might change, if it's a `QWidget`](https://doc.qt.io/qt-6/qwidget.html#winId):

QWidgets are typically given their own QWindow if they don't have a parent, so in this example it shouldn't change since the widget isn't moving windows
There are a couple ways for a [QWidget to be given a window handle](https://doc.qt.io/qt-6/qwidget.html#native-widgets-vs-alien-widgets), they aren't given by default apparently.
My example uses option 5 already `setAttribute(Qt::WA_PaintOnScreen);`
